fields.description:
If you get the details of a review which has a patch, 

E.g.

[http://localhost:8060/rest-service/reviews-v1/CR-63/details]

You get:

{code:xml}
...
<patchUrl>/cru/CR-63/downloadPatch/1/TAC-1513-patch.txt</patchUrl>
...
{code}

I.e the url includes "downloadPatch" with capital P, however going to this url gives a 404 because the crucible action:

{code:xml}
<action name="downloadpatch" class="com.cenqua.crucible.actions.DownloadPatchAction">
            <result name="success" type="stream">
                <param name="contentType">${contentType}</param>
            </result>
            <result name="error" type="dispatcher">/WEB-INF/jsp/crucible/common/generalError.jsp</result>
        </action>
{code}

is for downloadpatch.
fields.summary: Rest Api returns the wrong URL for download Patch
FishEyeData0BinBackup should include all of var/data

fields.description: The QuartzManager stores its quartzcron.properties file in the instance directory, which is not covered by any of the backup items.
fields.summary: Quartz cron file is not covered by backup

fields.description:
In the post below I added a script for creating Crucible review items using the REST API based on Subversion commits.  Note that I had to do significant extra work to gather the information necessary to create a review item.  I think this could be improved greatly to the point where Crucible allows you to send a revision number and respository ID through the REST API.  The Crucible/Fisheye web UI already allows this to some extent so the logic must already exist in some form.

http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?messageID=257304368&#257304368
fields.summary: Create REST API call to allow adding review items to a review based purely on revision number

fields.description:
In the forum post below I have an example of a script making calls to the Crucible REST API.  Note that in order to add a Subversion commit to a Code Review I had to make a single call for every item which was committed.  This is inefficient for the majority of commits and likely causes unnecessary strain on the Crucible server.  I suggest allowing the passing of <reviewItems> to the API instead of or in addition to single <reviewItem>.

http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?messageID=257304368&#257304368
fields.summary: Create or modify REST API to allow adding several review items at a time

fields.description: Customers would like the ability to add custom fields to reviews.
fields.summary: Add plugin point to be able to create custom fields
Put Linked Jiras back in place
Return removed features to the 3 pane ui

fields.description:
*How to Reproduce*
# Perform 2 or more commits on one single file (e.g. rev2 and rev3 for file {{test.txt}}) in any SCM (e.g. Perforce in this case).
# Create a new Crucible review, click on tab "Manage Files">"Files".
# Add (check) {{test.txt}} into this review.
# Go back to tab "Review", and will see the file has description of "2 to 3 diff" (see sample screenshot at attached {{s01.JPG}})
# Go to FishEye, and look for revision 2 and 3. 
# Only revision 3 has the corresponding review id, but revision 2 has nothing (see sample screenshot at attached {{s02.JPG}})

*Problem Statements*
This would lead to misunderstand whereby the people who look at FishEye changelog will not know exactly which revision has been reviewed.
fields.summary: FishEye only indicate Crucible review for a file with latest revision

http://skitch.com/prutser/bmain/cr-fe-1539-cruc-1242-delete-the-old-backup-mechanism-under-review
http://img.skitch.com/20090414-84aw9n45praxd19u6pcp6d54m8.jpg

https://extranet.atlassian.com/crucible/cru/CR-FE-1539

fields.description:
Please add options to ignore whitespace when viewing diffs. I'd prefer it was not part of the profile (or only there as a default) but available in the diff options per file as they're being reviewed.

Options such as:

Include whitespace
Ignore leading whitespace
Ignore trailing whitespace
Ignore whitespace completely
fields.summary: Options for ignoring whitespace on diffs

fields.description:
I spend a lot of time time in Crucible doing reviews. So I've gotten used to clicking on the name of the file and it expanding out the diff. It's a lot easier to hit that target so I always do that instead of hitting the little arrow on the left, which also expands the diff.

So when I open up anything in FishEye, and click a file to open the diff, I always end up going to the file history. I do this pretty much every time - go to the history by accident, then hit back, then aim for the little arrow and then do the diff. 99% of the time I'm looking at a changelist in FE I want to see diffs and not go to file history.

I don't know what can be done about this, but I wanted to bring it up because it constantly trips me up. And it's really slow to make this mistake over the VPN link too. :)
fields.summary: Inconsistent file click UI between FishEye and Crucible

fields.description:
Say somebody makes a comment in a review on code that hasn't changed. Someone else viewing this review in only context diff mode will see the comment and "comment skipped on line xx".

Showing the "comment skipped" is not a good way to do it. The only way to see what the comment is about currently is to show the full diff. For a very large file this becomes a major pain. Not to mention how it really breaks the workflow of running through a code review. You have to stop what you're doing, go to the top of the file, turn on show full diffs, find the comment again, review the area, then go back to context diff. It makes people not want to bother looking at the code the comment is about.

My suggestion is simply to show this comment in context with lines around it, as if there was a change on that line. Should solve the problem nicely.
fields.summary: Comments should be considered part of the diff when not showing full diff

Add comment counts to the frx tree

fields.description:
*How to Reproduce*:
# Goto FishEye search page, and issue query statement "{{select revisions where (not in any review)}}". This is to find all revisions that do not have any associated review.
# The result of this search query is being shown in attached screenshot {{screen-01.jpg}}.
# However, the revision #40 is not supposed to be listed here because it is partially being reviewed under CR-53 (see {{screen-02.jpg}}). In this example, only {{/branches/b02/helloworld.java}} and {{/branches/b02/another.txt}} are checked for the review process, but not {{/branches/b02}}.
# If I include {{/branches/b02}} into the review, then it will not be listed anymore when I issue that query.
fields.summary: Find revisions that do not have any associated review - it still shows revisions that are partially belong to a review.

fields.description:
If a repository is stopped, missing, or it's config has changed (excludes etc), crucible should always make a best-effort attempt to display the details, and should never throw an excpetion. If we have stored content, we should ALWAYS serve it.

If the repository is stopped or deleted, reviews will display error "repository not available" even if you have store contents of file in review

Steps to reproduce 

1) In Administration > Projects, ensure your project has [Store the contents of files in reviews|http://confluence.atlassian.com/x/HwftCQ] checked. 
2) Create review and add files from fisheye repository to the review. 
3) Stop the fisheye repository in Administration 
4) Go back to the review and try to expand the files. 

(Testing on trunk seems to show that this issue has been fixed, but would like it confirmed with a test added, so we do not have a regression).
fields.summary: Crucible MUST serve CrucibleRevisions it has, regardless of FE repository status.

fields.description:
*Problem Statement*
When user create a new Crucible review, the listed users (either reviewers, moderators or authors) are in unorder form. Please see the attached pictures ({{pic01.jpg}}, {{pic02.jpg}})

*How to Reproduce*
# Create users, if not exist (preferably 6-10 users for testing purpose)
# Create a group named "TestGroup" and assign those users into this group.
# Goto Administration>Projects>Edit Default Project
# Add "TestGroup" as Default Reviewers and Allowed Review Participants
# Goto Crucible dashboard to create a new review and we will be able to see the above mentioned problem.
fields.summary: Unorder list of Reviewers if they are in a group (as Default Reviewers & Allowed Review Participants)
Springify Backup Manager

fields.description:
We need the following (the list is a subject to grow :)):
* ability to create post-commit review from provided list of files (paths) and associated info (per each such file: "from" revision (null means take whole file from "to" revision) and "to" revision). Currently API supports only creation of review basing on changesets - i.e. we cannot add individual files
* a method which would return the data about the traffic/content of the repository:
a. like in Manage Files | Changesets (so list of changests + files inside) - for selected repository and time period
b. like in Manage Files | Files (repo content) - for selected repository and path (directory)
This data would be used to create review in aforementioned manner
* a method which would send a path (or list of paths) to Crucible which in turn would try to map it to the corresponding indexed/accessible resources and returned some kind of identifier (e.g. repo id + full path) and returned matches to the client. We would use this method to somehow map between local resources (available in IDE) and resources available to Crucible server. E.g. we would send src/java/some/package/X.java and Crucible would answer myrepo:/trunk/myproject/src/java/some/package/X.java. This method should support querying for any number of paths (files or directories) in one call.
* a method to get allowed reviewers (according to permission scheme) for:
a. selected review
b. new review being just created for selected project
* a method like setReviewers(Collection<String> reviewers) - currently we need to call addReviewers + many times (for each reviewer) removeReviewer. Non transactional, slow (latency, multiple marshalling/unmarshaling) and sucks
* a method like updateReviewDetails(...) - to be able to modify things like: author, moderator, title, statement of objectives, allow anyone to join (and ideally also reviewers) - generally everything except for files and comments themselves. This method could be also broken into N separate methods like: setModerator, setTitle, setAllowAnyoneJoin, etc. - to improve potential collision handling and allow clients to send only such data which should really be changed

Please remember that we don't want to depend on FishEye - so even though some methods can be already available via FishEye, I think they should also be available in standalone Crucible.

Improvements:
* existing createReview* should automatically set reviewers if they are provided by the client. Currently we need many calls to achieve this simple thing 
* for pre-commit review we would like to be able to associate the files with some concrete revisions - i.e. Crucible would allow to review in some wider context (by applying the patch on existing and indexed repository data).

Of course we would love to have it all for 1.7 :)

Our engineers are complaining that they are getting spammed by crucible putting at risk the implementation of crucible in the company. Do we still need the drop downs now that we have iterative reviews?

fields.summary: Crucible does not handle incomplete record data (via REST API) properly

fields.description:
Say we have a Fisheye repository tracking commits from the root of a Subversion tree:

SVN URL:  	file:///var/lib/svn
SVN Path: 	/

Later we realise that we only want Fisheye tracking stuff in /projects.  So we change the SVN Path:

SVN URL:  	file:///var/lib/svn
SVN Path: 	projects

and reindex.

Then someone notices that *all the old fisheye reviews are broken*.  The HTML is cut off halfway through the page:

!brokenreview.png!

and the logs are full of stacktraces:

{noformat}
ERROR - Nested in javax.servlet.ServletException: javax.el.ELException: java.lang.NullPointerException:
javax.el.ELException: java.lang.NullPointerException
        at javax.el.BeanELResolver.getValue(BeanELResolver.java:266)
        at javax.el.CompositeELResolver.getValue(CompositeELResolver.java:143)
        at com.sun.el.parser.AstValue.getValue(AstValue.java:138)
        at com.sun.el.ValueExpressionImpl.getValue(ValueExpressionImpl.java:206)
        at org.apache.jasper.runtime.PageContextImpl.evaluateExpression(PageContextImpl.java:984)
        at org.apache.jsp.tag.web.review.frxDisplay_tag._jspx_meth_c_if_6(org.apache.jsp.tag.web.review.frxDisplay_tag:856)
        at org.apache.jsp.tag.web.review.frxDisplay_tag._jspx_meth_c_when_1(org.apache.jsp.tag.web.review.frxDisplay_tag:691)
        at org.apache.jsp.tag.web.review.frxDisplay_tag._jspx_meth_c_choose_1(org.apache.jsp.tag.web.review.frxDisplay_tag:637)
        at org.apache.jsp.tag.web.review.frxDisplay_tag.doTag(org.apache.jsp.tag.web.review.frxDisplay_tag:279)
        at org.apache.jsp.WEB_002dINF.jsp.crucible.review.monolithic.review_jsp._jspx_meth_rev_frxDisplay_0(org.apache.jsp.WEB_002dINF.jsp.crucible.review.monolithic.review_jsp:5724)
        at org.apache.jsp.WEB_002dINF.jsp.crucible.review.monolithic.review_jsp._jspx_meth_c_forEach_28(org.apache.jsp.WEB_002dINF.jsp.crucible.review.monolithic.review_jsp:5680)
        at org.apache.jsp.WEB_002dINF.jsp.crucible.review.monolithic.review_jsp._jspx_meth_c_when_17(org.apache.jsp.WEB_002dINF.jsp.crucible.review.monolithic.review_jsp:5643)
        at org.apache.jsp.WEB_002dINF.jsp.crucible.review.monolithic.review_jsp._jspx_meth_c_choose_11(org.apache.jsp.WEB_002dINF.jsp.crucible.review.monolithic.review_jsp:5609)
        at org.apache.jsp.WEB_002dINF.jsp.crucible.review.monolithic.review_jsp._jspService(org.apache.jsp.WEB_002dINF.jsp.crucible.review.monolithic.review_jsp:672)
        at org.apache.jasper.runtime.HttpJspBase.service(HttpJspBase.java:93)
 ....
Caused by: java.lang.NullPointerException
        at com.cenqua.crucible.revision.source.RepositorySource.getLatestRevIdent(RepositorySource.java:434)
        at com.cenqua.crucible.revision.source.RepositorySource.isAnySuccessorRevisions(RepositorySource.java:424)
        at com.cenqua.crucible.view.FRXDO.isAnySuccessorRevisions(FRXDO.java:219)
        at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
        at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39)
        at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)
        at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:585)
        at javax.el.BeanELResolver.getValue(BeanELResolver.java:261)
        ... 116 more
{noformat}

What has happened is that Crucible reviews contain file paths relative to the Fisheye 'SVN Path'.  Changing 'SVN Path' effectively breaks every review in Crucible.

If you're lucky enough to catch the problem early and realise the cause, you can change back to the old path, and reviews will again be accessible.  If you're unlucky, people start creating new reviews with the new path, and now you've got a choice of 'losing' old reviews or new reviews, as both paths cannot be correct.
fields.summary: Changing Fisheye repository path breaks all associated Crucible reviews

fields.description:
In a very large organization, manually adding users to a review can become time consuming.
The feature "Invite someone to a review" is perfect for these cases, but it requires you to have Public sign-up turned on.   This does not work in corporate environment that use LDAP authentication as sign-up accounts get created as "built-in", and most LDAP auth setups have auto-creation on log-in turned on.

It would be a great help if you can make Invite to Review work with LDAP auth and turned off Public Sign-up
fields.summary: Make "Invite to Review" work with out public sign-up on (IE: for when LDAP Authentication is on)

fields.description: See case [https://support.atlassian.com/browse/CRC-609]
fields.summary: Regression of CRUC-526 in crucible 1.6.6

fields.description: We have two reviews, in which we see files marked as ADDED when they we actually EDITED, no ADDED in the changelist being reviewed. Is this a known issue?
fields.summary: Files marked as ADDED in a review when they were actually EDITED, not ADDED

fields.description: Server-side performance must be improved.
fields.summary: Crucible Performance Improvements
Delete the old backup mechanism
Rewire the quartz job

fields.description:
When deleting a defect, Crucible automatically deletes the Jira subtask that it is linked to. However, when communicating with jira fails, the comment is still deleted, leaving the subtask behind.
We should pop up a confirmation dialog in that case that tells the user that the issue cannot be deleted. Pressing "confirm" then just deletes the comment.
fields.summary: Ask for delete-comment confirmation when the linked jira cannot be deleted

fields.description: this is a test comment for creating a subtask on jac
fields.summary: this is a test comment for creating a subtask on jac

fields.description: Test for {{CommentManager.getFrxRevisionReadInlineCommentCount()}}
fields.summary: Unit test for frx revision read/unread comment counts
Revision slider hardening/tweaking

fields.description:
It'd be great if you could start a crucible review by clicking on a button next to a patch that is attache to a JIRA issue and a new review would be created.

The title of the review could contain the issue id and the title of the issue.
fields.summary: Allow patches from JIRA to be imported directly into crucible

fields.description:
It would be great if Crucible could provide an option that allows users to specify that word-wrapping should be enforced. In situations where a text file needs to be commented on and that text file contains long text lines e.g see the attached [screen shot|http://jira.atlassian.com/secure/attachment/30934/wrap.png ] (which looked fine in the text editor I used to create it - it probably had visual word-wrapping turned on by default), Crucible could help perform that visual word-wrap to allow users to easily read the content.

Obviously the word-wrapping that Crucible might implement should be visual only (i.e. not alter the meaning of line numbers) and adjust automatically based on the browser window size.
fields.summary: Wrap option
